title: 112_hr3012
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011" and includes a numerical limitation to any single foreign state. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to make changes to section 202 and 203, including adjustments to numerical limitations for foreign states. The Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1152) is amended to make changes to subsections (a)(3), (a)(5), and (e), specifically addressing special rules for countries exceeding immigrant visa limitations under section 203(a). The Nationality Act is amended to allocate visa numbers to natives of specific countries under section 203(a) in a proportional manner. Additionally, amendments are made to the Chinese Student Protection Act of 1992 regarding country-specific offsets. The effective date of these amendments is specified. The Nationality Act is amended to allocate visa numbers to natives of specific countries in a proportional manner. Amendments are made to the Chinese Student Protection Act of 1992 regarding country-specific offsets. The amendments made by this section shall take effect as if enacted on September 30, 2011, and shall apply to fiscal years beginning with fiscal year 2012. Transition rules for employment-based immigrants are outlined, including the allocation of immigrant visas for fiscal year 2012. For fiscal years 2012 and 2013, a percentage of immigrant visas under specific paragraphs will be allotted to natives of foreign states not among the top two states with the highest number of visas in 2010. For fiscal years 2012 and 2013, a percentage of immigrant visas under specific paragraphs will be allotted to natives of foreign states not among the top two states with the highest number of visas in 2010. In fiscal year 2014, 10 percent of immigrant visas under each paragraph will be reserved for natives of states not among the top two with the highest visa numbers in 2012. In fiscal years 2012 and 2013, a percentage of immigrant visas will be allotted to natives of foreign states not among the top two states with the highest number of visas in 2010. In fiscal year 2014, 10 percent of immigrant visas under each paragraph will be reserved for natives of states not among the top two with the highest visa numbers in 2012. Per-country levels for reserved and unreserved visas are specified. In fiscal years 2012 and 2013, a percentage of immigrant visas will be allotted to natives of foreign states not among the top two states with the highest number of visas in 2010. In fiscal year 2014, 10 percent of immigrant visas under each paragraph will be reserved for natives of states not among the top two with the highest visa numbers in 2012. Per-country levels for reserved and unreserved visas are specified. Additionally, a special rule allows for the issuance of unused visas in certain circumstances for fiscal years 2012, 2013, or 2014. In fiscal years 2012 and 2013, immigrant visas will be allotted to natives of foreign states not among the top two states with the highest number of visas in 2010. In fiscal year 2014, 10 percent of immigrant visas will be reserved for natives of states not among the top two with the highest visa numbers in 2012. Unused visas may be issued without regard to certain subsections. Rules for chargeability apply in determining the foreign state an alien is chargeable to. The House of Representatives passed the bill on November 29, 2011. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
